I don’t even know if there is a test for ‘how much weed you have in your system’ like the Blood Alcohol Content test for alcohol, but I’d think that would be something that needs ironed out in the legislation that legalizes it. item.title: 5 Pro-Marijuana Arguments That Aren't Helping
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

I don’t doubt that some people drive fine under the influence of many things, but the problem is that it is dependent on the individual. For example, I can’t drive stoned for shit. It makes me twitchy, nervous, overcautious and paranoid. I’ve driven many times on amphetamines, however, and I do just fine. This isn’t to say that it’s OK to drive high (everyone’s been young and stupid), quite the opposite, that since we can’t apply a rule to every individual, we ban it for all of them. There’s no situation ever where somebody NEEDS to drive high - if you know you have something important to do, don’t get high. If something important comes up when you’re already high, it better be a matter of life or death before you get in the car, and in those situations an ambulance is a better choice.

And again, this has no bearing on legalisation.

item.title: 5 Pro-Marijuana Arguments That Aren't Helping
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

For what it’s worth, impairment is induced by sleep deprivation as well. In fact, the graphs that describe alcohol-induced impairment and sleep-dep induced impairment are both exponential, and virtually identical after the 24 hours of being awake.

In Australia, we have a legal driving limit of 0.05 BAC (blood alcohol concentration). You can have two drinks and stay under it if you’re male of average weight and height.
The point I’m making is similar to Greeny’s, I suspect. Ultimately we accept mild levels of impairment, otherwise it’d be a zero BAC across the board.
The problem with marijuana is that, being illegal, nobody can quantify ‘acceptable’ or mild impairment levels.

I don’t agree with intentional drink driving, even when it is below the limit. I think someone should go out of their way to avoid driving if they’ve had anything to drink.
But I do think acceptance of low range BAC isn’t the end of the world for those people who have no alternatives.
My opinion for marijuana is similar, but the problem is the lack of information on the quantity that you can smoke before passing that mild level of impairment that society allows.

item.title: 5 Pro-Marijuana Arguments That Aren't Helping
item.dc:creator: @Holic Holic
item.description:
@Holic wrote:

Moparisthebest:

if a little kid ran out in front of you, you would probably kill them when it could have been avoided if not impaired.

I hate this example for a few reasons.

  1. If a little kid ran out in front of you, ANYONE could hit the kid regardless of their current mental state. It’s a surprise, people fuck up a lot when they’re surprised no matter what.
  2. For the past 3 years I have driven to a viewpoint over my town and smoked. It’s a 5 minute drive to my house from there. I’ve made it home every single night safely. I live on the coast of BC meaning there is a ton of animals. I pass/avoid about 6 or 7 deer/rabbits/raccoons every night, and never hit a single one. They are more of a surprise than a child, deers jump from the hills onto the road.
  3. ‘Heavy users’ of marijuana don’t get stoned like you might, MITB. I’ll smoke a blunt to myself, straight to the dome, and I know I’m stoned but at the same time, I’m not impaired. I feel sober, I don’t feel much different.
    Heavy smokers back me up here. It doesn’t make sense to those who have never indulged in drugs.

Now, I’m not saying we can all smoke up and drive, yadayadayada. I’m just saying that that argument is a shitty one.
I will never, ever drive when I’ve been drinking, no matter how much. We have a zero-tolerance law in BC for learners and new drivers. It’ll soon be in place for all drivers.

We should be allowed to make the decision ourselves of what we put in our bodies. I am a medical user (not cancer) and with weed in my life, sleeping, eating and everything have become a lot easier and all around a lot more enjoyable.
